body: IN an aluminum shed among postcard orchards in Columbia County in New York, Derek Grout inspected a collecting tank of his state-of-the-art copper-pot still. A blocked vent had caused the tank to buckle. ''I'm just kind of glad we didn't kill ourselves,'' he said with a laugh. ''Got to bang that out.'' He has been working with it for only two
title: Just Don't Call It Moonshine

body: For Children 'Amahl and the Night Visitors' (Saturday) A disabled boy offers the baby Jesus the gift of his crutches in this 1951 opera by Gian Carlo Menotti, which has become a Christmas favorite. This year the Little Orchestra Society, which offers the work annually in its Happy Concerts for Young People series, has mounted an entirely new
title: Spare Times

body: This weekend Rooftop Films goes underground for two afternoons to show movies in the Atlantic Avenue tunnel in Brooklyn. On Saturday the event is Trapped in the Tunnel, a program of short films about people who venture into unknown territory, like an insurgent's cave in the Iraqi desert, an abandoned coal mine in Pennsylvania and, in ''Covered
title: WEEKEND MISER; Weekend Miser

body: Send me your own dining questions via dinejournal@nytimes.com or Twitter.com/samsifton. Q. Recently, my wife and I left Manhattan in search of space and quiet and ended up in Fort Greene. It's a great area, with nice restaurants and awesome farmers' and flea markets. But I yearn to find those familiar locations that we adore so in the city, like
title: HEY, MR. CRITIC; Looking for Old Brooklyn? Nosh This Way

body: ''WHEN we first started Varnish, we began sustaining a bunch of injuries,'' Marcos Tello said. ''I had a huge, constant knot in my forearm. Chris Ojeda developed tennis elbow. Matty Eggleston popped a tendon in his hand. We were all sidelined with all these injuries.'' Varnish is not a football team. It is a stylish, speakeasy-style cocktail bar
title: HOLIDAY DRINKS ISSUE; The Bartender Appears to Be Shaken Up

body: Leonard Lopate is the host of a radio talk show, covering subjects like crafting and quantum physics, that is broadcast every weekday from noon to 2 p.m. on WNYC. Mr. Lopate, 70, spends Sundays with his girlfriend, Melanie Baker, an artist with whom he lives in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. That is the day that they usually restock the pantry with a visit
title: SUNDAY ROUTINE | LEONARD LOPATE; To Greenmarket, to Greenmarket

body: When David Black contemplated moving his 21-year-old literary agency to a new office space this summer, he had one nagging worry: the East River. ''Would that be a problem?'' Mr. Black said, pointing to the river from his 27th-floor office window, which boasts sweeping views of the Brooklyn Bridge and the Manhattan skyline. ''Is water a barrier to
title: No Bridge Too Far: Agents Move To Brooklyn

body: John McFadden Jr. jokes that his fate was sealed when he was born the same year his father bought Staubitz Market, a butcher shop in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that was established in 1917. Mr. McFadden, 43, got his start in the family business at age 10, sweeping up blood-soaked sawdust (the traditional butcher-shop floor covering). Now co-owner with
title: EXPERIENCE NECESSARY; A Butcher Who Lacks a Killer Instinct

body: All About Chocolate The annual Chocolate Show with exhibits, tastings, cooking demonstrations and chocolates for sale will be held from Nov. 11 through 13 from 10 a.m. to 7 p.m., and Nov. 14 from 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. at Metropolitan Pavilion, 125 West 18th Street. Tickets are available at $28 for those over 12 from chocolateshow.com, $30 at the door.
title: Calendar

body: Like many creative professionals who live in Williamsburg, Lewis Canfield possesses a Renaissance man's variety of passions and hobbies. He worked in the movie industry, profited from the Internet boom, dabbled in art, developed an interest in women's perfume scents and now buys, sells and renovates Brooklyn real estate. No topic has captured his
title: THE APPRAISAL; For One Real Estate Investor, Vinyl Siding Never Lost Its Shine

body: In ''Wilderness,'' a new movement installation presented by Dance Theater Workshop at the Invisible Dog Art Center, Yanira Castro continued her mission of fleshing out the relationship between two groups of people: those doing the watching and those doing the performing. Ms. Castro conceived and directed the piece, and choreographed it with her
title: DANCE REVIEW; The Mulch, The Tunics, The Lunges

body: Dance Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. - American Ballet Theater (Sunday and Monday) This holiday season, as children wriggle with anticipation over unopened gifts, New York balletomanes have their own present to look forward to: a new ''Nutcracker,'' choreographed by Alexei Ratmansky for Ballet Theater. Those who can't wait
title: The Listings

body: MY mother never let me have Pop-Tarts -- breakfast shouldn't involve frosting, was the theory -- but she would approve of the version sold at Ted & Honey, a snug cafe on Clinton Street next to Cobble Hill Park in Brooklyn. This freshly baked tart shares little, aesthetically or nutritionally, with its prepackaged namesake: A fragile shell of
title: NEIGHBORHOOD JOINT | COBBLE HILL; No Frosting For Breakfast? No Problem

title: The Listings

body: When is tap water so good it's worth fighting for? When it's almost as good as New York City tap water. A pair of restaurants in south Florida that claim to capture the unique liquid flavor of Gotham and transfer it to Palm Beach bagels and pizza are now engaged in just such a legal battle. The Original Brooklyn Water Bagel Company says it has
title: CITY ROOM; Tap Water In New York And a Fight In Florida

body: A familiar city ritual with a dog and a dog walker took place Monday evening at Smith and Wyckoff Streets in the Cobble Hill neighborhood of Brooklyn.
title: A Walk in the Shadows

body: In recent decades Baroque music has been the focus of much debate about authenticity and the importance of historically accurate performances. But in the Baroque era, musicians were far less reverential. In particular, operas known as pasticcios staged in the 17th and 18th centuries were freewheeling hodgepodges, offering fast-paced spectacles of
title: MUSIC REVIEW; Variety Show, With Arias Thrown In

body: NEW YORKERS have been rediscovering a small neighborhood in Brooklyn called the Columbia Street Waterfront District -- and so have the real estate developers. The opening of Pier 6 in Brooklyn Bridge Park last spring, and the recent completion of a bicycle and pedestrian pathway along Columbia Street, part of the Brooklyn Waterfront Greenway that
title: POSTING; An Area Growing in a Family Way

body: AFTER graduating from the Juilliard School, Monica Ohuchi Bunch practiced and taught on her upright piano. Two years ago, she upgraded to a Steinway Grand, Model B, nearly seven feet long. It had to be lifted, via crane, into the apartment she shared with her husband, Kenji Bunch. They watched with their hearts in their throats as it entered their
title: THE HUNT; A Place to Make Music, Minus Noise

Mr. Grigolo brings impassioned singing, good
title: The Listings

body: IT'S not exactly Poets' Corner of Westminster Abbey, but the blond-wood shelves at BookCourt in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, do confer a certain prestige in this literary-minded neighborhood. So it was at a recent Wednesday event, when a small crowd was leaving a reading from a graphic novel about the Cuban revolution by Inverna Lockpez and Dean Haspiel,
title: UP CLOSE; Same Old, Same Old

body: A RECENT article on ArtThreat.net examined the Internet mini-sensation of the graffiti artist Banksy's animation intro for ''The Simpsons.'' In the clip, Banksy lampoons the outsourcing of Simpsons animation cels to South Korea by showing the characters being drawn by candlelight in damp underground sweatshops. ArtThreat quoted Naomi Klein's
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER; Where the Well Heeled Dress Down

body: Classical Daniel J. Wakin The conductorVALERY GERGIEV has done things in a big way in New York. In the past four years he has traversed the works of Shostakovich, Prokofiev and Stravinsky at Carnegie and Avery Fisher Halls, with the London Symphony, Mariinsky Theater Orchestra and New York Philharmonic. This week, it is Mahler's turn. On Sunday he
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | OCT. 17--OCT. 23

body: ABINGDON SQUARE PARK, a 0.222-acre triangle of greenery in the West Village, is not a place that requires much time for exploration. A lap of its curving byways, around a manicured garden island, takes just a minute or two. Indeed, most everyone there on a recent sunny Saturday was partaking in the square's main day-to-day activity: sitting on
title: Breathing Room

body: Long Island College Hospital, a financially troubled community hospital in Brooklyn, has been saved from the threat of closing or bankruptcy through a planned merger with SUNY Downstate Medical Center, a major public university and medical center, Gov. David A. Paterson and hospital officials said Thursday. Long Island College Hospital, known as
title: Merger Will Save Hospital In Brooklyn, Officials Say

body: With the long-awaited opening this week of a Barneys Co-op branch in Brooklyn, the borough's Atlantic Avenue -- long a shoppers' mecca of independent designer boutiques and well-trod antiques stores (with the occasional bail-bond agent thrown into the mix) -- gets a powerful magnet store that's sure to draw even more of the city's shopaholics to
title: BROWSING; Next Stop, Brooklyn

body: BENKERT--Ernst G.,82, died October 5th, 2010 after living for three and a half years with angiosarcoma, a rare form of cancer. With him at the end were his children, Louly Williams and Edward Benkert, his grandchildren, Ellie and Max Williams, and his companion of twenty-eight years, Alexandra Walcott. He is also survived by a brother, Kyle
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BENKERT, ERNST G.

body: BENKERT--Ernst G.,82, died October 5th, 2010 after living for three and a half years with angiosarcoma, a rare form of cancer. With him at the end were his children, Louly Williams and Edward Benkert, his grandchildren, Ellie and Max Williams, and his companion of twenty-eight years, Alexandra Walcott. He is also survived by a brother, Kyle
title: Paid Notice: Deaths BENKERT, ERNST G.

body: For Children 'Angelina Ballerina the Musical' (Friday through Monday) That winsome white mouse who does all her scurrying in toeshoes is ready to pirouette onto the stage in this musical adaptation from Vital Theater Company. Based on the books by Katharine Holabird and Helen Craig and the PBS series ''Angelina Ballerina the Next Steps,'' the show
title: Spare Times

body: IT may be Brooklyn's most televised stoop since the Huxtables'. Claire Danes, Hilary Swank and Andy Garcia have sat there. So have Ashanti, Ray Davies and Pete Wentz. And if Cat Greenleaf, the host of a surprise breakout show called ''Talk Stoop'' has her way, the stoop outside her humble Cobble Hill three-story town house will become a regular
title: UP CLOSE; Welcome, I've Cleaned a Step for You

body: VALERIE BERGER was nearly 60 but had never had her own place. She split her time between her mother's house and her boyfriend's apartment, both in Park Slope, Brooklyn. Then her boyfriend died of a surgery-related infection at age 70, a few years after her mother did. Unable to afford much else, Ms. Berger moved in April 2009 into the Y.W.C.A. in
title: At the Y, 'They Take Care of Each Other'

body: Like many New Yorkers, the people of Brooklyn Heights have something of a love-hate relationship with the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway. On the one hand, the highway is the bane of the neighborhood, carrying trucks whose startling rumbles often wake the sleeping, and spewing dust and fumes onto leafy streets named Cranberry, Pineapple and Willow. But
title: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS JOURNAL; As Aging B.Q.E. Faces Reconstruction, Ideas Turn to Tunnels

body: 'THE MAGIC ORANGE TREE' CELEBRATION When Diane Wolkstein listened to news reports after the January earthquake in Haiti, she continually heard references to that country's extreme poverty. She found the descriptions heartbreaking, she said, because in her view Haiti has at least one source of great wealth. ''It's not poor in culture,'' said Ms.
title: Spare Times: For Children

author: E-mail: susan.dominus@nytimes.com
body: The music on ''Silver and Ash,'' a new album from the songwriter Clare Burson, started with silence. There was the silence that descended in 1941, when letters from her maternal great-grandparents, German Jews who had fled to Latvia, abruptly stopped arriving in Memphis, where Ms. Burson's grandmother settled in 1938. Then there was the second
title: BIG CITY; From Silence, Songs About the Holocaust

body: Epaulet makes custom shirts, this right? ''selvedge'' appears more frequently on Web and appeared in Critical Shopper column selvage jeans and corduroys in a shade of lime called ''go-to-hell green.'' Welcome to D.I.Y.-crazed Brooklyn. The emphasis at this modest Cobble Hill storefront is on fabric and fit: Epaulet's button-fly chinos (from $135),
title: REMIX; Now Stitching - Brooklyn Shirting Gallery

body: A New York City police officer was suspended without pay on Tuesday after an encounter with the mother of an 11-year-old girl who was suffering an asthma attack and later died, the authorities said. The officer, Alfonso Mendez, 30, who joined the force in 2005 and was assigned to the 84th Precinct, was expected to face administrative charges of
title: Officer's Actions Questioned After Asthmatic Girl Dies

body: 270 Court Street (Butler Street), Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; (718) 855-2105. Flexing its muscles in Cobble Hill is this new sister spot to the already popular Bocca Lupo. Given its 24 rotating taps of well-curated American beer (standouts of late included bittersweet Founders Red's Rye and chocolatey North Coast Old Rasputin), it's been called a
title: DINING BRIEFS | RECENTLY OPENED; STRONG PLACE

body: Openings L'OUBLI GOURMET BAR Benjamin Demarchelier, above, whose father, Eric, owns a classic bistro on the Upper East Side, is definitely not in competition at his place, where small, French-style plates dominate the menu. If a Lower East Side address is not enough to dissuade the high-toned Park Avenue crowd, the no-reservations policy should do
title: Off the Menu

body: COBBLE HILL DUPLEX $799,000 BROOKLYN: 121 Pacific Street (between Henry and Clinton Streets), Apt. A1E In a 46-unit 1984 converted warehouse, a two-bedroom, two-bath duplex co-op with a home office, working fireplace, central air-conditioning, washer/dryer and common roof deck. Steven Gerber, Corcoran Group (718) 923-8014; www.corcoran.com Open
title: ON THE MARKET

body: CLOSING After four years, the on-trend men's store BBLESSING is closing on July 31. ''It's been really busy, and in a way fun, with a lot of familiar faces stopping in,'' said Nicholas Kratochvil, men's wear manager and designer for the BBlessing Collection. Mr. Kratochvil cited other empty storefronts in the neighborhood as leading to less foot
title: Scouting Report

body: EVERY now and again, during the six years that Mary Beth and Alan Maginn lived in a one-bedroom apartment on the ground floor of a two-family row house in Park Slope, they toyed with the idea of moving. Over time, their rent rose to $1,975 a month from $1,700. They occasionally checked online to see what else was available, only to conclude they
title: THE HUNT; Escape From Quirkyville

body: Seasonal Farm Stands Brooklyn Grange, a community farm in Queens, has scheduled seasonal farm stands, on Tuesdays and Thursdays from 3 to 7 p.m. in the lobby of the Standard Motor Products Building, and at the farm, 37-18 Northern Boulevard, Long Island City; and on Sundays from 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. at Roberta's, 261 Moore Street (Bogart Street),
title: Calendar

body: WHEN it comes to biking, New York is no Amsterdam. But that hasn't stopped Ad Hereijgers, an urban planner from the Netherlands, from opening a Euro-style bicycle store in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that specializes in Dutch imports. That includes sturdy cargo and commuter bicycles by De Fietsfabriek (from $1,500) and Dutch ID (from $1,400), as well as
title: BROWSING; From Amsterdam To Cobble Hill by Bike

body: The Ruler of Late Night ''Florent: Queen of the Meat Market,'' a documentary on Florent Morellet's now-defunct restaurant in the meatpacking district, will have its world premiere on June 24 as part of the NYC Food Film Festival. The event, which is also sponsored by the James Beard Foundation and will benefit the Food Bank for New York City, will
title: Calendar

body: For Children 'Amazon Voyage: Vicious Fishes & Other Riches' (Friday through Thursday) The anaconda isn't real, but the piranhas are. In this simulated trip down the Amazon, a new exhibition at the New York Hall of Science, children can learn about the creatures of the river, their adaptations and their life cycles. The exhibits include live
title: SPARE TIMES

body: The new ''Food Lovers' Guide to Brooklyn'' by Sherri Eisenberg (Globe Pequot Press, $14.95) is reasonably up-to-date for a borough where new food places open their doors by the minute. Its 328 pages are packed, district by district, with detailed listings, maps and descriptions. Some of the neighborhood groupings segue from one into another, like
title: FOOD STUFF; A Borough's Treats, Now in a Book

body: New York City apartment buildings are often a menagerie of types, including old-timers who remember precisely who lived in each apartment 25 years ago, midlifers preoccupied with their families, and residents so new that they still find the clanging radiators and groaning midcentury elevators charming. But one outgrowth of the real estate
title: THE APPRAISAL; An Apartment Building Where Babies Reign

body: YOGA is about casting off petty annoyances and toxic judgments -- a seemingly Sisyphean task for those hopped up on New York City living. But what if irritation trails you right onto your mat, in the guise of ring tones, exhibitionists or bliss-busting interruptions? Is there no compact of dos and don'ts inside a yoga studio? Not really. Common
title: STRETCH ETIQUETTE FOR YOGIS; Invasion of the Serenity Saboteurs

body: 'TIGERS THE EXHIBITION' The most common way of getting inside a tiger isn't much fun -- just ask the deer in Asia. But now children in New York can inhabit a Bengal tiger through means that are risk free and entertaining, allowing them not only to see the creature's bones and muscles but also to perceive the world through its senses. That
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: A red cloth bulletin board that has been turned into a memorial captures the loss that struck Public School 29 in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, last Wednesday. There is a child's pencil drawing of a grave with a tombstone that reads, ''BEST food ever, richert.'' There is a note, written by the still-learning hand of a kindergartner: ''RichaRd, I MiSS you
title: CITY ROOM; At P.S. 29 in Brooklyn, Mourning the Abrupt Loss of a Beloved Cook

Beth Kenkel (917) 543-2115, Nick Ferrone (718) 923-8090, Corcoran Group; www.corcoran.com COMMON CHARGE: $590 a month, plus a capital

body: Brooklyn, the new bastion of cool for many New Yorkers, is poised to go mainstream chic. The announcement that Barneys Co-op will open its first store in Cobble Hill has cleared the way for other nationally recognized high-end retailers to make a similar move across the bridge, according to brokers who specialize in representing luxury clothiers.
title: SQUARE FEET; High-End Retailers Are Scouting Sites in Brooklyn

body: ANDREA SYRTASH realized one day why she should marry her good friend Michael Paoli. Because he was the one person she wouldn't mind being stuck in a foxhole with. And so, when the couple moved from their native Toronto to New York, taking over a tiny Greenwich Village one-bedroom from a friend, Mr. Paoli hugged his wife and said, ''We're in our
title: THE HUNT; An Apartment That's Just Their Type

body: Josh Ritter has a way with metaphor. It's one of the literary touches in his music that have established him among the cream of the young singer-songwriter crop, and it is all over his albums: romantic diplomacy in a missile silo; Columbus's doomed fourth ship; a mummy whose curse is the realization that love is mortal. It was no big surprise,
title: Flying Low, but Staying on Folk's Radar

body: IN early April, Kris Comstock, a representative for the Buffalo Trace distillery in Kentucky, conducted a seminar on bourbon at Char No. 4, a bar in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that offers 150 kinds of American whiskey. Among the bourbons he poured were Buffalo Trace, Eagle Rare and Blanton's. But his students weren't interested in those. ''The first
title: White Dog: A Whiskey Having Its Day

body: ON New York's hurried streets, one passing cyclist can appear no different from another. But cyclists are hardly a monolithic subculture -- more like a collection of finely divided sub-subcultures, each with its own uniform, lingo and attitude toward the bicycle's place in the urban landscape. Bike messengers continue to hold their place as iconic
title: SPOKES; Two-Wheeled Tribes

body: The real estate firm Two Trees Management is expanding the Dumbo Arts Festival in Brooklyn, adding a greater diversity of programming to a mix that already includes visual art and performances. The festival will now be organized by a variety of arts professionals, rather than solely by the Dumbo Arts Center, which founded it. The festival, entering
title: ARTS, BRIEFLY; Brooklyn Festival Grows

body: 'ADVENTURES WITH DORA AND DIEGO' (Friday through Sunday, and Tuesday through Thursday) The young Latino stars of the Nickelodeon animated television series ''Dora the Explorer'' and ''Go, Diego, Go!'' have taken their expeditions into new territory at the Children's Museum of Manhattan, whose exhibition has separate Dora and Diego environments,
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Ah, Greenpoint, Brooklyn. A neighborhood at once blessed and cursed. Upside: It borders the East River and has glorious views of Manhattan's spires. Downside: Much of the waterfront is blocked off by a grim stretch of decaying industrial sites. Upside: A subway runs through its heart. Downside: The train is the widely loathed G. Upside: Its
title: On a Magazine's List of the City's 'Most Livable Neighborhoods,' a Few Surprises

body: MARIA BERMAN was hopelessly smitten with the working fireplace in her first New York apartment, a third-floor walk-up in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn. ''That fireplace was in use most of the year,'' said Ms. Berman, an architect who lived in the apartment in the early 1990s. ''For three years I had quarter cords of wood delivered to my doorstep.'' But in
title: Charmed Obsolescence

body: Doua Moua, 23, played a menacing gangster in a Clint Eastwood movie, but Mr. Moua swears he really is a nice, gentle and rules-abiding fellow. At least he was until he moved to New York City and unwittingly slipped into a world of lawlessness. Mr. Moua lives with five roommates. And in New York, home to some of the nation's highest rents and more
title: Only Three To a Home? Who Knew?

title: Spare Times

body: Onstage Cuisine On March 18 to 20 at 8 p.m. and March 21 at 2:30 p.m. at La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street (Second Avenue), there will be a production of ''La Vie Matérielle'' by Irina Brook based on the writings of Marguerite Duras and Virginia Woolf, in which members of the cast will cook onstage, with leftovers available for sampling
title: Calendar

body: CONTES--Eileen B.,on March 11, 2010. Beloved wife of Zachary. Devoted sister of Chris and Elizabeth Costas. Loving aunt and godmother to many. Reposing at Cobble Hill Chapels, 171 Court Street, Brooklyn, NY until Tuesday, 10:30am. Funeral service at S.S. Constantine and Helen Greek Orthodox Church, 64 Schermerhorn Street, Brooklyn, 11:30am.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths CONTES, EILEEN B.

body: IN the living room of the apartment in Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, that Robert Highsmith, 27, shares with his girlfriend, Stefanie Brechbuehler, 32, and their standard schnauzer, Kingsley, is a weathered Eames lounge chair that once belonged to Mr. Highsmith's grandfather and still smells faintly of cigarette smoke. A painting by his grandmother, an
title: ON LOCATION; Where Provenance Presides

body: NEW YORK used to be a second-string city when it came to coffee. No longer. Over the last two years, more than 40 new cafes and coffee bars have joined a small, dedicated group of establishments where coffee making is treated like an art, or at least a high form of craft. At places like Bluebird Coffee Shop in the East Village, the espresso is so
title: What's the Buzz?

body: 'THE PAPER BAG PLAYERS GREAT MUMMY ADVENTURE' For the next three weekends several Manhattan theaters will resound with the voices of small children cursing: loudly, lustily and with full adult approval. This is not another sign of society's moral deterioration; these oaths have more to do with ancient Egypt than with streetwise attitude. In the
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: The Environmental Protection Agency designated the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn a Superfund site on Tuesday and announced plans to clean up more than a century's worth of noxious pollutants there. The decision ended a contentious debate and was a blow to the Bloomberg administration, which had proposed a cleanup without such a designation. The city
title: E.P.A. Readies Cleanup Plan For Gowanus

body: Don't be alarmed if your children tell you they want to spend the weekend inside the Invisible Dog. They don't need a trip to the therapist -- just to Brooklyn. The Invisible Dog is an art center that will be the site of the first Brooklyn Inventgenuity Festival, an urban Woodstock for budding young scientists, engineers, artists and dreamers.
title: Spare Times For Children: Brooklyn Inventgenuity Festival

body: When Jennie Dundas and Alexis Miesen opened Blue Marble, a shop selling homemade ice cream on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, back in 2007, their checklist included organic ingredients, 16 percent butterfat and a child-friendly setting. Soft-serve ice cream was not in the picture there or at their second shop, in Prospect Heights. ''It
title: FOOD STUFF; Ice Cream Makers Embracing Their Soft Side

body: Fighting Hunger Tom Colicchio will be a host, with Natalie Portman, at a benefit on Feb. 21 with food and drinks at Colicchio & Sons, 85 10th Avenue (15th Street), for the Feed Foundation's program called Hungry in America. title: Calendar

body: More than a half-dozen gentrified neighborhoods in Brooklyn would lose subsidized day care centers for low-income families under proposed city budget cuts, Bloomberg administration officials said Wednesday. A list of the 15 day care centers that are scheduled to close in July, 10 of them in Brooklyn, was released by the Administration for
title: City Seeks to Close 15 Day Care Centers, Most in Brooklyn, in Budget Cut

body: Panhandlers in this city are often ignored, stiffed, even reviled, but sometimes, if they hang around long enough and take the right approach, they can work themselves not only into the wallets, but also into the hearts of those they solicit. Such was the case with Tom, the Concierge of Court Street. Tom was the guy who held the door for you at
title: In Brooklyn, Court Street Pays Tribute to a Fixture

body: BY midafternoon on a recent Saturday, Bierkraft, the beer emporium and grocery on Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, Brooklyn, was half-filled with customers, many of them parents with babies or toddlers in tow. They were browsing the more than 1,000 varieties of bottled beer or surveying the listing of selections available on the 13 taps and 3 cask
title: The New Old Way To Tote Your Beer

body: THE view from the Brooklyn Heights Promenade, a five-block walkway that has overlooked New York Harbor from its perch at neighborhood's edge since 1950, is almost the same as it was 60 years ago. The Lower Manhattan skyline rises up, seeming close enough to touch, against a backdrop of clouds; tugboats push barges to and fro; cars and trucks race
title: LIVING IN | BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; The 360 From Here

body: FOR CHILDREN BIG MOVIES FOR LITTLE KIDS (Monday) Many children learn to sing ''Yellow Submarine'' in preschool. Now they can hear it in its original context: the wildly colorful, fancifully animated Beatles film of the same title from 1968. Expect them to learn a new word: psychedelic. At 4 p.m., Cobble Hill Cinemas, 265 Court Street, at Butler
title: Spare Times for Children

body: URBAN renewal. The phrase conjures up government-backed megaprojects from the '70s, but it's organic to New York, where someone is always getting off the bus, train or plane. In the last year, the city has opened a hot new park, Lincoln Center celebrated its 50th anniversary with a major face-lift that includes a new fountain with 353 custom-made,
title: 36 Hours: New York City

body: Laura saved Anthony. They first met in 1993, when she was 20 and he was 34 and they were both in recovery programs, undergoing treatment for mental illness. He was shuttling between home and inpatient psychiatric units and spotted Laura at a day clinic. ''I felt like I always knew her,'' he said. Back then, she had a crush on someone else. Thirteen
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Engaged, Employed and Wrestling With Mental Illness
